1122970566116413446.text: Opening party to @CADAFNYC digital art fair is SOLD OUT. Party is still accessible with a  multi-day pass (come on people, it's only $25). Register now before this ones goes too: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/cadaf-nyc-contemporary-digital-art-fair-tickets-60289658993 … #artfair #friezeweek #digitalart #digitalartfair #nycarts #nycpic.twitter.com/K5ibUMAA4Y

1123003617877696512.text: So now my pet theory is that someone (maybe me, and I forgot???) is airdropping these fake tokens into random wallets.. but 1) why me and 2) why do this at all? Are they trying to confuse users by impersonating legit tokens?

1123003612651671552.text:
After scouring through my historical transactions, I found it: an ERC-20 token with the symbol "ETH" that some random address had sent me 100 of. Twice.

The kicker? I sent one of those tokens to _another_ random address. And I have no memory of that!?

1123003635032395776.text: So there _is_ a bug that I've reported to cointracker: they resolve the market value an ERC-20 token using the symbol "ETH" with the same market data as native mainnet ETH. Easily fixed, but certainly silly in hindsight.

1123003614375567360.text:
At this point I'm wondering 1) how to sweep all of the assets that this account controls (ps: no clue how to track them all down) and 2) why nothing was stolen when the key is obviously compromised.

But I'm still investigating: what's with this ETH token contract?

1123003615214313472.text:
So I take a peek: This "ETH" contract [0] is still being used, even as recently as a day ago (?!) and all transactions are 1 or 100 tokens...

Ok, let's look at the code... nothing—except 17 identical contracts?? [1]

[0] https://etherscan.io/token/0xb0c433fa6a4bf5496173801f5cc6bbc93a9e40a2 …
[1] https://etherscan.io/find-similar-contracts?a=0xb0c433fa6a4bf5496173801f5cc6bbc93a9e40a2&lvl=5 …

1123003617076580352.text: (hilariously, if I had clicked literally _any_ of those other identical token contracts, I would have come to the correct conclusion, and yet...)

1123003618687275009.text: Next stop: checking literally every address I control to see if any of these mystery addresses (like, who deployed these copy-cat tokens?) is one of mine... and nothing. The only address of mine implicated in this is that daily driver. What. The. Fuck?

1123003620352389120.text:
As it turns out, each one of those addresses is one of the identical copies of our ETH token, except for one.

It's got a _lot_ of these faux-token (faux-ken?) transactions [0].. maybe it's an exchange? Why was I making these txs??

[0] https://etherscan.io/address/0xa7cd6cc6b7bdb26b7732d6a58fd39b8f243c8393#tokentxns …

1123003611825332224.text:
They get back to me with a quick: "nothing weird on our end—did you enter that transaction manually?", which strikes off the obvious bug theory.

I certainly didn't manually enter a 200 ETH transaction so I could pay more taxes, so what on earth is happening?

1123003621308751872.text:
A quick google search for the offending address, and here we are: https://github.com/zeppelinos/crafty/blob/master/zos.mainnet.json#L15 …

Yup, it's the https://crafty.zeppelin.solutions/  contract. All of them are. @mrnventuro and I wrote this a year ago.

And of _course_ I interacted with them, _obviously_ I did!

1123003627595939840.text:
I was crafting a very important token: Pixel, the adorable Zeppelin doggo!

Turns out you need a ZEP token and a DOGE token to make Pixel, ETH and TOOLS to make ZEP, and BTC and IDEA for DOGE.

And there they are: the two transactions to mint 100 faux-ETH, from myself, to myself.pic.twitter.com/Bwin8jVndV

1123003616179019781.text:
So I check out these other contracts: there's one called "BTC" [0] and another called "AIR" [1], and at this point it's obvious to me that these things are just impersonating popular token symbols... but why??

[0] https://etherscan.io/address/0x5a363278b7cbbe300dc26b4684f23820cf24bfa7 …
[1] https://etherscan.io/address/0x02361abf7f8e50812bcdd932f94e348bc4f96f4e …

1123003633665056768.text:
So, we found out who stole my private keys: me.

¯\_(ツ)_/¯pic.twitter.com/bBXdm94c2h

1123003622361452545.text:
Remember how I was in the air at 5pm PST? Turns out that @etherscan displays tooltip times in UTC, but without mentioning the timezone, which made me think it was client-local.

5pm UTC in SF is... 10am, which puts me comfortably at home, pre-flight.

1123003619517710337.text:
I take a look through my historical transactions on etherscan this time, trying to figure out wtf I was doing that morning of the flight... and I find 11 (eleven!!) transactions all within the same hour, to a bunch of different addresses.

But, a clue!!

1123003613511426048.text:
_Another_ kicker? At the time of that transaction 5pm on July 22nd, 2018, I was 30,000 miles in the air on the way from SFO to Hong Kong for the NIFTY conference.

And you bet your ass I'm too poor to justify plane wifi. So... what on earth is happening?

1118241968851570688.text:
Today on @digitallyrare we chat with the OG Crypto Punks known as @pents90 and @matthall2000!

 Discussing artistic narratives, the mustache Autoglyph, and wayyy more

 Find us on your favorite podcast player or listen on the web right now:https://overcast.fm/+N6TGsBJVo

1123003635867086848.text:
Anyway, that's a well-learned lesson on the fragility of human memory and the completely opaque nature of bitcode on a blockchain.

Also, go play Crafty, it's an oldie-but-goodie!

https://crafty.zeppelin.solutions/

1123003623204483072.text:
But, we launched nearly two months earlier on May 24th (featured by @Flynnjamm on June 6th: https://medium.com/@brianubiquik/crafting-new-value-with-existing-tokens-de95fe838fea …)

... so what was I doing playing Crafty just hours before I had to leave my house for a flight to Hong Kong?
